results.title: Tom Brown's School Days
results.brief_description: In this marvellous Hollywood version of British public school life, Tom Brown finds life at Rugby brutal, but eventually helps to become a civilising influence for his schoolmates. Immediately on arrival at Rugby, Tom is befriended by a character named East and together they begin the age old battle against the schoolyard bully. This classic novel is a story of courage, survival of the initiation ritual, and the struggle for acceptance.

results.title: Tom Arthur
results.creator_credit: National Gallery of Victoria and Open Channel Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Survey (National Gallery of Victoria)”.
Tom Arthur’s art is for him a visual way of reasoning. By using the associated symbolic meanings and cultural connotations attached to specific objects and images he attempts to examine and question belief structures and systems of knowledge and how society forces these into its members. For Tom Arthur there are no absolutes, and everything seems relative

results.title: Tom & Viv
results.creator_credit: Samuelson Productions, Harvey Kass, IRS media, British Screen, New Era Entertainment, Marc Samuelson, Peter Samuelson and Brian Gilbert
results.brief_description: The extraordinary story of the passionate, all-consuming and finally, destructive love between T.S. Eliot, one of the greatest poets of the 20th Century, and his first wife, Vivienne, a vivacious yet disturbed society beauty. History has long forgotten the woman who had such a lasting impact on Eliot’s life and whose mental deterioration had such a lasting influence on his writing. With honesty, compassion and daring, Willem Dafoe and Miranda Richardson bring to the screen the lives of two people whose destinies would be linked forever but whose love was doomed. Co-starring Rosemary Harris, Tim Dutton and Nickolas Grace. Based on the play by Michael Hastings.

results.title: Tolstoy after Anna Karenina
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The 19th Century Novel”.
After publishing Anna Karenina Tolstoy suffered a crisis in his personal and public life. The question which in Anna Karenina haunts Levin “Why am I?” became more and more urgent to Tolstoy and his answers became more extreme. He was a man who craved solitude, but his admirers almost made this impossible for him. Tolstoy died on 7 November 1910. Documentary also features Russian writers Godky and Chekov. Uses archival footage and stills.

results.title: Toller
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Pen Densham and John Watson
results.brief_description: Hailed as “the world’s most exciting and innovative figure skater”. Canadian, Toller Cranston, is the subject of this film. Apart from being a brilliant ice skater, Cranston is also an accomplished fine artist with numerous painting exhibitions to his credit. The film shows several skating routines in full, depicting Toller’s original style and how sometimes he uses some of his painting ideas in his skating routines. Features the World Championships at Colorado Springs.

results.title: Tokyo story = Tokyo monogatari
results.brief_description: Ozu considered what many regard as his finest film to be about the disintegration of the Japanese family system. Ordinary family events - the visit of parents to see the children and their cool reception - are profoundly moving as Ozu portrays them. ‘Tokyo Story’ is actually a recasting of Leo McCarey’s ‘Make Way For Tomorrow’ which his collaborator, Noda, had seen but Ozu had not. As in most of his later films there is a pervasive nostalgia, a sense of loss. Although a loosely plotted leisurely survey of the extended family structured around journeys, the film is full of conflicts triggered by the grandparents’ visit in which characterisation both enriches and qualifies stark thematic oppositions.

results.title: Tokyo Olympiad [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: 13th Olympic Games Organising Committee, Suketaro Taguchi, Kon Ichikawa and Toho Kabushiki Kaisha
results.brief_description: Ichikawa’s compression of the many hours of footage shot by 164 cameramen using 1031 cameras at the 1964 Olympics is the only sporting documentary to rival Riefenstahl’s Olympia. In contrast to Riefenstahl’s heroic paean to the human body, Ichikawa seeks out and pays tribute to human fallibility using the telephoto lens, slow motion and freeze frame, to probe and generate empathy. In place of a mundane and prosaic record of national teams competing in a succession of events, Ichikawa takes the occasion to stay in close with selected individuals, winners and losers, striving to overcome their limitations. As in Riefenstahl’s film the climax is the marathon, here presented as a tribute to, rather than a celebration of individual effort. A phenomenally successful film upon its theatrical release, Ichikawa illustrates that a search for human understanding sometimes presents insurmountable difficulties, sometimes there is room for optimism, but more often the ironic truth is that a gold medal provides no answer to the problems of living.
